attributes.comment:
As a Medical Doctor, I am opposed to the term "provider".

This blurs the line between the rigorous medical training of a physician, and someone like an NP or PA, with less than 3% of the time in training, and with orders of magnitude less content, depth and rigor.

Further, the term "provider" was first utilized by the Third Reich, to denigrate Jewish physicians.

I don't "provide" services. I practice medicine, and deliver expert care to my patients.

The term "provider" obfuscates the level of training and expertise of the person rendering treatment; it confuses patients. Indeed, non-physician caregivers often want to be thought of as physicians by patients, and do not dissuade patients of the belief that they are being cared for by a physician, when they are not.

Labelling everyone as a "provider"makes all healthcare professionals appear equivalent. They are not.

It is best to refer to all health care professionals by their actual credentials, to accurately reflect training and degrees, and avoid confusion.

Physicians need their own directory, as they are a singularly distinct category of healthcare professional, and should be leading healthcare.
